comment.narrative: - Three Provinces have finalized the SDG platform Themes and potential organization (Province 2 on Resilient Cities-Extraction of Natural Resources, Gandaki Province- Green Finance and Karnalai Province- Food Security) are finalized - 11 local governments prepared the periodic plan and start implementing - UNDP has developed and rolled out a dedicated socio-economic and livelihood recovery package. The package program aims to increase the basic income of vulnerable groups by promoting local resource-based enterprises- on farm based and off farmed. - 12,386 households were directly benefitted from socio-economic recovery interventions to improve their income and livelihood - 18 socio-economic recovery project in partnerships with municipalities implemented.
- Three SDG platforms established in 2020 will be functional

description.narrative: Recovering Back Better and Strengthening Resilience for the Most Vulnerable COVID-19-Affected Rural Communities
first-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: At least 4-6 counties supported to recover back better and strengthen resilience for COVID-19

comment.narrative: N/A
At least 4-6 counties supported to recover back better and strengthen resilience for COVID-19

5 counties supported to recover back better and strengthen resilience for COVID-19 First, the CO supported China's emergency response and recovery by focusing on vulnerable populations. This included saving lives of COVID-19 patients who were critically ill and front-line responders, through the provision of medical equipment (584,374 USD of clinical electrocardiogram monitors, infusion pumps, 10,000 sets of protective clothing). Second, the CO provided technical leadership on the UN socio-economic impact assessment, which provides insights on effective policy prescriptions, particularly that with a focus on the pandemic's impact on the most vulnerable. Drawing from the assessment findings sampling 5044 individuals in 1,183 households, UNDP utilized the TRAC resources in 5 counties across 5 provinces in China for recovery support. Third, the CO implemented activities to help the most vulnerable population to build back better. Urgent livelihood needs of 400 vulnerable households (1,600 villagers) in Zhangwan (Hubei) were addressed due to UNDP's support on live streaming for e-commerce. Local farmers attracted 2.1 million customers through the livestreaming and increased their sales. Challenges in managing information and finance for local businesses were addressed as UNDP set up an information management platform, currently used by 8 businesses. Fourth, the CO enhanced local public health and other basic social services, including education, in Neixiang (Henan), Zhouqu (Gansu) and Yilong (Sichuan), during the COVID and to prepare for future pandemics. 85000 students in Neixiang gained access to psychological support and received better education, as UNDP trained 960 teachers across the county on psychological support and communications. 680 patients (392 are female) in 19 villages directly benefited from the medical equipment donated by UNDP in Zhouqu; 40 doctors and nurses were fully trained to use the donated respiratory machine; 10 clinical electrocardiogram monitors and 50 first-aid kits. In Yilong, 10 villages received PPE and doctors and nurses in 5 hospitals were trained on epidemiology investigation and monitoring. Also, UNDP helped Yilong establish a long-term collaborative network with West China Hospital of Sichuan University to receive continuous technical support and guidance for pandemic control. Additionally, education recovery plans were developed in communities in Chengbu (Hunan) focusing on LNOB. 1,920 teachers have enhanced capacity on online education as UNDP mapped out the local education improvement needs and provided 8 training courses. The 2020 TRAC (175,000 USD) managed to leverage and mobilize another 1,005,046.50 USD to directly benefit 4 additional counties in 4 other provinces, in addition the Zhangwan District of Shiyan City in Hubei, the epicenter of the COVID-19 in 2020, as proposed in the application document.
project closure

Ampliar capacidades para fortalecer el diagnóstico molecular de la COVID-19, en laboratorios de La Habana y laboratorios regionales, ubicados en Villa Clara y Santiago de Cuba. Así como fortalecer la captura, procesamiento de datos y gestión de información en las Salas Situacionales del Ministerio de Salud Pública y del Estado Mayor Nacional de la Defensa Civil (EMNDC). Además del fortalecimiento del control de infecciones en centros de atención a pacientes sospechosos o confirmados de padecer la COVID-19.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1- Number of national updates on the COVID-19 that include information on the molecular tests performed. 2- Number of national and local institutions with infraestructure and operational capacities strengthened to assure their efficient and effective performance in the face of COVID-19 3- Number of new audiovisual and printed promotional material produced

comment.narrative: 1. 90 actualizaciones realizadas 2. 12 instituciones nacionales y locales fortalecidas 3. 8 productos comunicativos realizados

1. Desde marzo de 2020, el gobierno cubano y el Ministerio de Salud Pública, establecieron mecanismos para informar a la población la evolución de la enfermedad y alertar sobre la protección ante su incidencia en el país. Una vía es la habitual Conferencia de prensa que diariamente se transmite por los canales de la televisión nacional y otras redes de comunicación. Al frente de esta Conferencia de prensa está el Dr. Francisco Duran García, director nacional de Epidemiología del MINSAP. Cada día se muestra información relevante relacionada con la recolección, análisis e interpretación de datos, que permite explicar a la población, de forma concisa, la evolución de la enfermedad. A través de gráficos, tablas y mapas se presenta esta información y se interpreta detalladamente cada dato expuesto. Con el fortalecimiento de la Sala Situacional del MINSAP, se pudo generar información para los partes diarios de actualización transmitidos por las cadenas nacionales de radio y televisión. A partir de agosto y hasta octubre de 2020, la información recogida en los partes incluía la utilización de los suministros médicos con que apoyó el proyecto, así como su impacto en los resultados alcanzados. Se realizaron 90 partes en 3 meses, con esta información. 2. Se fortalecieron 12 instituciones nacionales: Instituto de Medicina Tropical Pedro Kouri-IPK, 5 Laboratorios de Diagnóstico de La Habana de los Hospitales Hermanos Ameijeiras, Manuel Fajardo, Fructoso Rodríguez, Centro de Higiene, Epidemiología y Microbiología de La Habana y el Laboratorio de la Defensa Civil. Los hospitales clínico-quirúrgicos Miguel Enríquez, en La Habana y los hospitales provinciales clínico-quirúrgicos Arnaldo Milián Castro, en Villa Clara y Saturnino Lora, en Santiago de Cuba. La Sala Situacional del MINSAP y Prosalud. En la Sala Situacional del Ministerio de Salud Pública, apoyada con equipamiento informático, se pudieron manejar, de manera efectiva, informaciones clave para la entrega de datos y pronósticos esenciales a las autoridades sanitarias y de gobierno competentes; para la toma de decisiones. Se transmitió información relevante relacionada con la recolección, análisis e interpretación de datos, que permitió explicar a la población, de forma concisa, la evolución de la enfermedad, por los canales de la televisión nacional y otras redes de comunicación en Cuba. Se pudieron realizar video-conferencias, con las provincias y varias instituciones involucradas, facilitando una mejor organización del trabajo. Se adquirieron 3 equipos de ultrasonido o ecógrafos para vigilancia y diagnóstico de pacientes con comorbilidades y sospechosos de COVID. Se ubicaron en hospitales clínicos-quirúrgicos de La Habana, Villa Cara y Santiago de Cuba. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos TRAC y fondos programáticos de PNUD. Se fortaleció el control de infecciones en centros de atención a pacientes sospechosos o confirmados de padecer la COVID-19, con: 59 Kits de diagnósticos para PCR-TR, 4,000 medios de transporte para virus Puritam UniTrans-RT (UT-362) y 2,640 QIAam viral RNA minikit 240. Se realizaron 5,546 pruebas de diagnóstico por infección por SARS CoV-2 , exudados nasofaríngeos PCR-TR a 4,000 personas y extracciones de ácido nucléico viral a 2,640 personas. Se cubrió a más de 12,000 personas con estos insumos médicos.
Se proporcionaron medios de protección personal (EPP) y suministros en apoyo a la ampliación de las capacidades de admisión hospitalaria que garantizó la vitalidad de los servicios y el apoyo al personal clave del MINSAP y de la Defensa Civil, consistentes en: 40,000 guantes, 7,000 bolsas para desechos biológicos, 950 batas quirúrgicas, 8,352 mascarillas N-95 y 20,000 mascarillas IIR. Estos artículos fueron destinados al Instituto de Medicina Tropical Pedro Kouri-IPK y para 5 Laboratorios de Diagnóstico de hospitales La Habana y para el Laboratorio de la Defensa Civil. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos TRAC y fondos programáticos de PNUD. Se beneficiaron 41,000 trabajadores de Salud Pública. 3. Se ampliaron las capacidades para implementar campañas de capacitación y sensibilización con perspectiva de género, alineadas con la campaña nacional del MINSAP de prevención y reducción del riesgo de contagio por COVID-19, con: -10 productos comunicativos: conjunto de postales, sueltos, spot publicitarios, concurso “Quédate en casa, quédate en igualdad”. Todos los materiales tuvieron en cuenta las consideraciones de género. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos TRAC y fondos programáticos de PNUD, hasta completar y superar el indicador de 10 productos comunicativos. Se realizó una amplia cobertura por los medios de comunicación nacional. Particularmente en redes sociales, con un alcance de más de 55 000 personas.

description.narrative: UNDP COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility Resources: 1) Ensure public Safety During an Emergency and social stability in the country; 2) Transition to a new model of management decision-making
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1) a) A toolkit for initial testing and a roadmap for scaling up nationwide b) Set of recommendations on redeployment of labor force in the face of the crisis 2) a) Analytical report of technical limitations, legal and organizational obstacles for full scale telecommuting and business continuity on national, oblast and local levels. b) 1,000 civil servants and several psychologists have completed courses on effective telecommuting and business continuity.

comment.narrative: There is a need to redesign of youth apprenticeship scheme and development of a toolkit for initial testing and a roadmap for scaling up nationwide. There is a need to development of practical recommendations on redeployment of labor force in the face of the crisis. There is a need to build capacity of 1,000 civil servants for effective telecommuting and business continuity

­2.1 Redesign of youth apprenticeship scheme, development of a toolkit for initial testing and a roadmap for scaling up nationwide. 2.2 Testing the toolkit by engaging 150 preselected young women and men who are temporarily jobless due to COVID-19 restrictive measures and reduced economic activities in select regions in public and private sector organizations. Scheme is to be supplemented by professional trainings introduced and implemented. Depending on the needs of particular cities or districts, apprenticeships will include seasonal works (floods), support to people most hit by the crisis (elderly, PWDs), support for social care services to address women’s additional burdens of unpaid care work with children, the sick, and elderly. 2.3 Development of practical recommendations on redeployment of labor force in the face of the crisis in addition to measures already introduced by the Government in view of a systematic approach to active employment measures for vulnerable groups. ­3.1 Review of civil service rules for home-based work, wage subsidies, sick leaves etc. in order to respond to the pandemic. Analise technical limitations, legal and organizational obstacles for full scale telecommuting and business continuity on national, oblast and local levels. Develop a package of proposals for rapid implementation. ­3.2 Building capacity of 1,000 civil servants for effective telecommuting and business continuity, including effective self-management, teamwork, maintaining social interactions with colleagues, maintaining high levels of motivation and performance. Separate trainings for managers on leading by example in crisis setting. ­3.3 Training and deployment of 5 psychologists for providing psychological help and counselling to civil servants not coping well with the crisis pressures and rapid change in working arrangements. Physical and IT infrastructure of the Public Administration Academy will be utilized as platform for delivering psycho-social counselling and advice. ­3.4 Preparing recommendations for introductions into the public administration reform process.

2.1-2.2. UNDP provided employment opportunities to 150 at-risk youth as part of its COVID-19 response program. Young people, who lost their jobs to the pandemic, took part in a subsidized three-month apprenticeship programme, accompanied by soft skills training and mentorship. The apprentices were placed in private companies, NGOs and government agencies in Nur-Sultan, Almaty and Karagandy region. They were encouraged to try out a new profession and gain experience, while receiving a ₸60,000 monthly allowance. The companies were monitoring the apprentices and hired the best performers. Of the total number of 150 programme participants, most were women, who also make up over 90 percent of the recipients of targeted social assistance in Kazakhstan. Overall, the project involved 25 mentors who were specifically trained for working with vulnerable youth. They conducted regular group and individual meetings with the apprentices. The internship also encouraged young people to pursue entrepreneurship in the future. Thanks to the new skills and knowledge acquired during the internship, about 20 percent of interns found additional funding sources for the implementation of their ideas and initiatives 2.3. Recommendation were developed as part of the SEIA. 3.1. Barriers for effective teleworking analyzed and 12 business processes selected for accelerated automation. Developed the package of specific proposals and recommendations for digitizing business processes of HR management in the public sector. 3.2. Around 2,000 civil servants were surveyed within the scope of Rapid Real Needs Assessment of Civil Servants in Crisis setting and under teleworking modalities in order to reflect the real training needs of civil servants in the current crisis. 1,006 civil servants of the central and local executive bodies of Kazakhstan, including 391 civil servants with disabilities, were trained on effective teleworking, with a specific focus on digital and communication skills. The content of the training was specifically designed for Kazakhstani civil servants following the President’s decision to switch to teleworking for 70 % of the civil servants. 3.3. UNDP CO hired a psychologist-consultant, who conducted individual psychological sessions not only to the staff of the Civil Service Agency, but their spouses and even their children. The sessions were conducted online at a convenient time for the staff by an appointment. Overall, within one month there were 3 group video conferences (sessions) and 27 individual sessions. 3.4. The Government with the UNDP CO support commenced work on the end-to-end digitalization of Kazakhstani civil service to make it “digital by default”. This implies digitizing 100 % of all the HR management related activities. As a first step, recruitment and testing are being digitized to minimize the need for the physical presence of the candidates.

comment.narrative: zero

1.1: 30 local government representatives and multi-stakeholder consulted including more than 40% of women 1.2: two assessment reports useful for the local governments and development partners for early recovery response targeting the most marginalized and vulnerable 1.3: Reaching out with risk communication and community engagement to more than 1 million people through two online portals, social media and IEC materials. 1.4: More than 50 people directly benefiting in at least one quarantine canton in the bordering towns of Sudurpaschim Province.

• 22 beds women isolation and holding center has been established to respond to protection issues of vulnerable women groups through multi-stakeholder approach and where 37 most vulnerable women like pregnant and disabled have been discharged. • An agro based digital platform has been established where local farmers of Dhangadhi could engage and share their agro products. This platform is expected to connect farmers and consumers even in hard times so that local supply chain is maintained and continued. This is yet to bring to formal operation. • A gender friendly quarantine center has been established to ensure women’s protection issues are addressed • Collaborated with Simraungadh municipality in Bara, to mobilize COVID-19 Prevention Group (CPG). As envisioned by the Volunteer Mobilization Guideline released by HLCC, the youth volunteer, as a part of CPG, are supporting local government to raise awareness on COVID-19 and encourage people to follow lockdown, facilitate people who came or coming from India and abroad to live in quarantine; conduct demonstrations on handwashing, coughing etiquette and other healthy behaviors etc. • Mahakali Municipality established a gender friendly quarantine spaces in Bhanu memorial school, where a separate block for women with improved gender and childcare facilities of 50 people capacity is established. Along the items supported by UNDP, the local government has provisioned a family space for those wife and husband with their children to stay together with social distancing. • An initiation with Ministry of Land Management, Agriculture and Cooperatives (MoLMAC) to develop livelihood information pack has started in Sudurpaschim Province. The pack is expected to proactively allow farmers to have easy access to information and help understand the government packages for them to uplift their economic status. • Communities at risk to COVID-19 has been mapped in Banke district to allow quick response to protection of these groups at risk to COVID-19.

description.narrative: Strengthening health systems to respond to COVID-19. UNDP is supporting Angola to strengthen the health systems in the face of COVID-19, including procuring urgently needed health and medical supplies.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

comment.narrative: Gaps on needs for COVID-19 health products and equipment in the country.

1.UNDP contributed significantly to the mapping exercise which highlighted critical funding gaps in the response. Seen as a critical technical partner in procurement, UNDP was invited by WHO to act co-administrator of WHO Angola Supply Portal for COVID-19 products. 2.With UNDP’s assistance, Angola’s CCM was able to mobilise 3.3 million USD from the Global Fund’s CR19 RM mechanism. Of this amount, 2.85 million USD will be managed by UNDP for the procurement of COVID-19 diagnostic tests, PPE for health professionals and community health workers. 3.UNDP was instrumental in helping the Ministry of Health issue its first Quantification Report for the COVID-19 response and in informing its review. The Report was well received by the World Bank which used it as the basis for the procurement of 15 million USD worth of COVID-19 health products and equipment; 4.The Luanda Provincial Government Strategy for Community Engagement in COVID-19 was finalized with technical assistance from UNDP. Also, an MoU was signed or the disbursement of 36,893USD allocated to the hiring and training of a cadre of 113 Community Volunteers. Another 25,000 USD were disbursed to ANASO which helped reach 14 584 families in Luanda’s municipalities with IEC materials on COVID-19. Food baskets were delivered to 2,125 families, including 850 adults and 350 Children living with or affected by HIV. UNDP has partnered with WHO and the Provincial Government of Luanda to promote hygiene and sanitation conditions in informal markets.

description.narrative: Socio-economic impact assessment of and recovery from COVID-19 and to find ways to mitigate them with sustainable, resilient and rights-based solutions crafted with the public and private sectors.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

comment.narrative: No socio-economic assessment for COVID-19.

1.Over 336.500 people reached by Emission of three radio programs per week in Otchivambo and Nhaneca-Humbe on climate change adaptation and disaster resilience through Radio Cunene, covering COVID aspects; 2.UNDP has technically led and conducted three socioeconomic assessments of the potential impacts of COVID-19 in Angola, including an additional assessment in partnership with UNCT and World Bank that contributed to elaborate the UN Socio-Economic Response and Recovery Plan. 3.Two MoUs signed with the Ministry of High Education and Innovation and Provincial Government to conduct the mapping of national entrepreneurship and innovation ecosystem in Angola. 4.Provided legal aid to over 600 women survivors of domestic violence. 5.UNDP provided support to provincial coordination, communication with Huila, Namibe and Cunene Covid-19 contingency plan was produced and established partnership with provincial vice-governors leading the DRM and Provincial Civil Protection Commissions. Governments, UNDP and EU developed the COVID-19 Monitor using Power BI and GIS Map.

1.Conduct a socio-economic impact assessment of COVID-19 pandemic on informal workers and informal economic units in urban areas 2.Provide technical advisory services to the Government for an assessment of social protection needs and extension of social protection to informal workers with priority to women and youth in urban areas 3.Support women, youth and members of key and vulnerable populations - with informal employment to register their businesses. 4.Strengthen business skills (business plan, seed capital management, accounting, marketing and e-marketing, finance and procurement, inventory control, soft skills and peer-learning among the female participants) of 300 women and young girls with informal employment, including at least 15 persons with disabilities and people living with HIV, through the attendance of vocational training courses 5.support the design and production of a distance learning distance learning package of vocational training, identified in dialogue with business associations, including procurement of the equipment needed 6.In partnership with INEFOP, Civil Society Organizations and business associations, support 400 women, young informal workers and members of key and vulnerable populations, who completed a vocational training course, to join an apprenticeship program in private and public companies and receive professional kits and tutoring 7.Mobilize private companies to expand their business opportunities through micro-franchising business models 8.Provide electronic equipment and conduct training on digital technologies (spreadsheet, emails, use of applications to run a digital business, digital marketing, e-commerce, data privacy, data protection and digital safety) to representatives of business associations of informal workers or informal economic units

comment.narrative: 1. Unavailability multi-stakeholder platform and partnership programme to enable inclusive multi-sectoral response at sub-national level. 2. Limited participation of women’s organizations, disable people organizations' and vulnerable groups in multi stakeholder platform to response COVID-1, in the context of patriarchal culture. 3. The spread of misinformation and communication delivered to target groups that risk perpetuating stigma and gender discrimination, in the situation of crisis. 4. 1. Inclusive and multi-sectoral coordination and public-private partnership platform established and operational at 5 (five) subnational level 2. Strengthened capacity of multi-sectoral platform and sub national governments on the gender-responsive policy advocacy and development at crisis situation 3. Raised awareness of # people to prevent and reduce stigma in relevant to those who associate with the outbreak corona virus diseases 2019 and gender equality at the context of crisis situation. (disaggregated by sex) 4. 1 responsive policy solutions developed

UNDP has successfully increased the co-ordination of capacity-mapping and provided technical support to 7 sub-national governments.It includes the the multi-stakeholders engagement to support inclusive response of COVID19, and to ensure protection to vulnerable group such as GBV victims/survivors,etc.
The needs assessment specific to pandemics has provided baseline support to recovery and contingency planning processes in 7 provinces. GBV case handling SOPs during pandemic at pilot police offices, local hospitals and the women and child protection units at the national and sub-national levels, were established (some are legalized and some are under finalization) to ensure reporting and referral channels are resilient and keep open in the middle of crisis. 10 workshops and training programmes with OPDs were conducted and have raised awareness and capacity of technical government agencies, OPDs, and community & family care services in preventing and handling COVID-19 cases for PwDs.
Communication strategy was implemented to reach massive audience, by conducting virtual seminars, communication campaign in public transportation such as MRT and LRT, Transjakarta and social media to blast the message of dangerous COVID 19 and readiness of governance to support protection of vulnerable groups during pandemic.

- Post-disaster need assessment conducted and recovery plan developed in 9 provinces - Raised awareness of # people to prevent and reduce stigma in relevant to those who associate with the outbreak corona virus diseases 2019 and gender equality at the context of crisis situation (disaggregated by sex).
